lessons.title: Lesson 1: How Pieces Move
lessons.description: Learn how each chess piece moves with interactive examples
lessons.content:
**Welcome to Chess!**

Let's learn how each piece moves. This is the foundation of everything in chess.

**The Pawn ♟️**: 
- Moves forward one square
- On first move, can move two squares
- Captures diagonally
- Special: Can promote when reaching other side

**The Knight ♘**:
- Moves in L-shape (2+1 squares)
- Only piece that can jump!
- Very tricky for beginners
- Great for forks (attacking two pieces)

**The Bishop ♗**:
- Moves diagonally only
- Each bishop stays on its color forever
- Light-square bishop and dark-square bishop
- Very strong when working together

**The Rook ♖**:
- Moves horizontally or vertically
- Any number of squares
- Very powerful in open positions
- Needs open files to be effective

**The Queen ♕**:
- Most powerful piece!
- Combines rook and bishop movement
- Can move in any direction
- Don't bring out too early (can be attacked)

**The King ♔**:
- Moves one square in any direction
- Most important piece
- If king is checkmated, you lose!
- Becomes strong in endgame

**Practice**: Try moving each piece around the board to get familiar!

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Special Moves
lessons.description: Master castling, en passant, and pawn promotion
lessons.content:
**The Three Special Moves**

**1. Castling (King Safety Move)**

Move your king two squares toward a rook, rook jumps to other side.

**Two Types**:
- Kingside castling (O-O): Short side
- Queenside castling (O-O-O): Long side

**Requirements** (ALL must be true):
- King hasn't moved
- Rook hasn't moved
- No pieces between them
- King not currently in check
- King doesn't pass through check
- King doesn't land in check

**Most Common Mistake**: Trying to castle through check!

**2. En Passant (Special Pawn Capture)**

If opponent's pawn moves two squares forward and lands BESIDE your pawn, you can capture it as if it only moved one square.

**Critical**: Must do it IMMEDIATELY (next move) or lose the chance forever!

**Why It Exists**: Prevents pawns from avoiding capture by using the two-square first move.

**Most Misunderstood Rule**: Many beginners don't know this exists!

**3. Pawn Promotion**

When pawn reaches opposite end, it MUST be promoted to:
- Queen (99% of the time)
- Rook
- Bishop  
- Knight (sometimes useful for forks!)

**Cannot promote to**: King or another pawn

**Strategy**: Race to promote pawns in endgame!

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Basic Checkmates
lessons.description: Learn how to deliver checkmate with different pieces
lessons.content:
**Essential Checkmate Patterns**

**Queen + King vs. King**:
- Easiest checkmate
- Push enemy king to edge
- Use your king to help
- Queen delivers mate
- Should take under 10 moves

**Two Rooks vs. King**:
- Very easy
- Use rooks like lawnmower
- Push king to edge
- Checkmate on back rank

**Rook + King vs. King**:
- Slightly harder
- Use your king to cut off squares
- Push enemy king to edge
- Rook delivers mate
- Learn this - comes up often!

**Back Rank Mate**:
- Most common checkmate pattern in games
- King trapped on back rank by its own pawns
- Rook or queen delivers mate
- **How to prevent**: Give your king an escape square!

**Smothered Mate**:
- Knight delivers checkmate
- King smothered by its own pieces
- Often follows a queen sacrifice
- Beautiful when it happens!

**Stalemate WARNING**: If your opponent has no legal moves but is NOT in check, it's a DRAW, not a win! Don't accidentally stalemate when you're winning big!

lessons.title: Lesson 4: Opening Principles
lessons.content:
**The First 10 Moves Set the Game**

**Golden Rules**:

1. **Control the Center** (e4, d4, e5, d5)
Why? Pieces in center control more squares, more mobility

2. **Develop Pieces Quickly**
Knights and bishops out early
Knights before bishops usually
Don't move same piece twice without reason

3. **Castle Early** (by move 10)
King safety is critical
Don't delay too long

4. **Don't Bring Queen Out Too Early**
She can be attacked
You waste time moving her multiple times
Develop minor pieces first

5. **Connect Your Rooks**
Clear back rank
Rooks work together

**Common Beginner Mistakes**:
- Scholar's Mate attempt (easily defended)
- Moving pawns aimlessly
- Neglecting development
- Ignoring opponent's threats
- Not castling

**Famous Opening Principles Quote**: 'A bad plan is better than no plan' - but a good plan is best!

lessons.title: Lesson 5: Tactical Patterns
lessons.content:
**The Building Blocks of Combination**

**Pin**: Piece can't move without exposing more valuable piece
**Example**: Bishop pins knight to king

**Fork**: One piece attacks two pieces at once
**Best at forks**: Knights! (L-shaped movement)

**Skewer**: Like reverse pin - valuable piece in front
**Example**: Rook attacks queen, pawn behind

**Discovered Attack**: Move piece, reveal attack from behind
**Powerful**: Two threats at once!

**Double Attack**: Two pieces attacking simultaneously

**Removing the Defender**: Eliminate piece protecting target
**Strategy**: Often involves sacrifice

**Deflection**: Force piece away from important square

**Decoy**: Lure piece to bad square

**Zwischenzug** (In-Between Move): Unexpected move in sequence
**Advanced**: Changes the position before expected response

**Pattern Recognition**: Study these until automatic!

Most tactics involve combinations of these patterns. The more patterns you recognize, the stronger you become!
